etymology.description: 艹(艹) (cǎo, "grass") + 叔(叔) (shū, "uncle") = plant-related term with phonetic value from 叔
etymology.interpretation: The character 菽(shū, "pulse") combines the semantic 艹(艹) (cǎo, "grass") to indicate a plant-related concept, with the phonetic element 叔(叔) (shū) to suggest its pronunciation. This reflects the agricultural context of 'pulse' as a type of leguminous plant.

examples.chinese: 农人耕种菽田(農人耕種菽田)，迎接秋收(迎接秋收)。
examples.pinyin: Nóng rén gēngzhòng shū tián, yíngjiē qiūshōu.
examples.english: The farmers cultivate pulse fields, welcoming the autumn harvest.

examples.chinese: 他用菽研磨出浓香豆浆(他用菽研磨出濃香豆漿)，享受健康生活(享受健康生活)。
examples.pinyin: Tā yòng shū yánmó chū nóngxiāng dòujiāng, xiǎngshòu jiànkāng shēnghuó.
examples.english: He grinds pulses to make fragrant soy milk, enjoying a healthy life.

examples.chinese: 春天里菽花绽放(春天裏菽花綻放)。
examples.english: In spring, the pulse flowers bloom.
